references: In Table                  1                , we see that across all three data settings considered,           ACT          achieves the strongest performance across all metrics compared to the other tuning approaches. Additionally, tuning with           ACT          in these limited data settings grants the model the ability to match our outperform frontier language models despite having zero in-context examples during inference.Overall,           ACT          appears to be helping to improve the recognition of ambiguity, as well as the ability to reason about clarifying questions. Additionally, the task-specific heuristics do appear to improve performance at the turn-level.

One of the key factors of             ACT            is that all of the contrastive pairs highlight differences between pragmatic actions (e.g. asking a question versus providing an answer). As indicated in the main results (Tables                     1                   ,                     2                   ,                     3                   ), we see that Naive DPO (i.e., when we sample preference pairings from LLMs without action specification) underperforms             ACT            . In Table                     5                   , we additionally examine the importance of action selection by randomly sampling             both the winning and losing action            when constructing the preference pair, and observe this underperforms normal             ACT            .

In all of our experiments with             ACT            , we used Zephyr 7B-                              Œ≤                                   ùõΩ                                  \beta                           , a version of Mistral 7B which has already been aligned with DPO. In Table                     5                   we also examine the impact of directly tuning two base foundation models, Mistral 7B and Gemma 2B. Directly comparing the baseline SFT performance with Mistral 7B against Zephyr 7B (see Table                     1                   ), we can see there is already a noticeable gap in all metrics. After applying             ACT            , while Mistral 7B‚Äôs performance does improve, it does not achieve the same performance as Zephyr.

references: Our results for Abg-CoQA are presented in Table                  2                . In all three data settings, we observe that           ACT          achieved the strongest performance in terms of task-specific metrics (notably, in terms of trajectory-level embedding similarity). However, in the 50 and 250 conversation condition, Naive DPO outperforms           ACT          in terms of Action Accuracy, and in the 100 conversation condition, SFT outperforms           ACT          in terms of Macro F1. Additionally, Gemini Ultra with Standard prompting outperforms all baselines in terms of Macro F1, Turn Similarity, and Trajectory-level similarity, although           ACT          with 250 conversations achieves comparable performance in terms of Trajectory-level similarity. This is likely because existing frontier LLMs can already achieve strong QA performance.

One of the key factors of             ACT            is that all of the contrastive pairs highlight differences between pragmatic actions (e.g. asking a question versus providing an answer). As indicated in the main results (Tables                     1                   ,                     2                   ,                     3                   ), we see that Naive DPO (i.e., when we sample preference pairings from LLMs without action specification) underperforms             ACT            . In Table                     5                   , we additionally examine the importance of action selection by randomly sampling             both the winning and losing action            when constructing the preference pair, and observe this underperforms normal             ACT            .

references: In Table                  4                we compare two trajectories produced by Zephyr 7B tuned on 50 conversations from PACIFIC using SFT and           ACT          , respectively, given the same conversation context and tabular information. The SFT model provided an incorrect answer to the user request, matching the ‚ÄúIncorrect Assumption‚Äù case in Figure                  1                . In contrast, the model tuned using           ACT          asked a clarifying question before eventually producing the correct answer. We provide additional qualitative examples in Appendix                  H                .

table: Macro F1 ‚Üë ‚Üë \uparrow Turn F1 ‚Üë ‚Üë \uparrow Traj. F1 ‚Üë ‚Üë \uparrow Post-Clarify F1 ‚Üë ‚Üë \uparrow Action Importance ACT w/ Random Actions 63.2 55.3 58.7 32.8 Ablation of ACT subcomponents ACT w/o on-policy sampling 74.8 61.5 59.1 40.5 ACT w/ sampling but w/o simulation 81.4 60.8 60.2 50.1 ACT (full) 82.2 62.8 61.9 57.2 ACT with unaligned foundation models Gemma 2B SFT 57.7 38.0 40.5 17.0 Gemma 2B ACT 62.7 42.6 44.0 24.8 Mistral 7B SFT 57.7 53.8 51.4 27.7 Mistral 7B ACT 75.7 58.1 57.6 31.9
references: One of the key factors of             ACT            is that all of the contrastive pairs highlight differences between pragmatic actions (e.g. asking a question versus providing an answer). As indicated in the main results (Tables                     1                   ,                     2                   ,                     3                   ), we see that Naive DPO (i.e., when we sample preference pairings from LLMs without action specification) underperforms             ACT            . In Table                     5                   , we additionally examine the importance of action selection by randomly sampling             both the winning and losing action            when constructing the preference pair, and observe this underperforms normal             ACT            .

In Table                     5                   , we also consider whether it is sufficient to remove sampling altogether, i.e. using the normal DPO algorithm on the action-based preference dataset as constructed in Section                     3.2.1                   . While we do observe some improvements over SFT (e.g., from 69.0 to 74.8 in terms of Macro F1 and from 57.8 to 61.5 in terms of turn-level DROP F1), the overall improvements are much larger when using on-policy sampling as with full             ACT            . This may be due to the fact that the LLM-sampled negative responses are not guaranteed to lie within the language manifold of the tuned policy model, making the training example too ‚Äúeasy.‚Äù Similarly, distribution shift is the key motivating factor the proposed online variant of DPO in             [               42              ]            .

We propose             ACT            as an approach which is better-aligned with multi-turn conversations due to its trajectory-level simulation from the policy model. In Table                     5                   , we find that removing trajectory-level simulation (while including on-policy response sampling for the purpose of determining pragmatic-level actions) results in degraded performance in terms of post-clarification DROP F1. This indicates that the model is better able to reason about its own clarification questions when tuned with trajectory-level simulation. We do note that this condition does outperform both SFT and             ACT            without any sampling (particularly in terms of Macro F1).

In all of our experiments with             ACT            , we used Zephyr 7B-                              Œ≤                                   ùõΩ                                  \beta                           , a version of Mistral 7B which has already been aligned with DPO. In Table                     5                   we also examine the impact of directly tuning two base foundation models, Mistral 7B and Gemma 2B. Directly comparing the baseline SFT performance with Mistral 7B against Zephyr 7B (see Table                     1                   ), we can see there is already a noticeable gap in all metrics. After applying             ACT            , while Mistral 7B‚Äôs performance does improve, it does not achieve the same performance as Zephyr.

id_table_7.caption: (highlighted in). Example 1) is a remnant of crowdsourcing in which the system-side party makes mention of the task guideline. Example 2) demonstrates a system-side clarification question being asked prior to the user making any information requests. Example 3) The system-side clarification question makes reference to some prior database search result, but the execution feedback is not made accessible to the system during inference.
table: No. Interacting Party Utterance User Can you list all the singer ids that aren‚Äôt present in the song table? Assistant SELECT Name FROM singer WHERE Singer_ID NOT IN ... User Thanks! 1 Assistant You should ask at least 3 questions 2 Assistant Did you want the full name of makers and the number? 3 Assistant Do you mean the address of the customer with first name Luis?
references: There is growing interest in using LLM-based agents for coding tasks         [           46          ]        . Particularly, due to the complexity of such tasks, multi-turn interactions in which an agent is able to clarify assumptions and user intents should intuitively help with goal completion         [           64          ]        . Despite this, there are few existing resources for multi-turn code generation tasks. One example is CoSQL, a conversational text-to-SQL task which also includes linguistic ambiguities         [           65          ]        , but the proposed task does not include agent-style interaction in which a model must learn to ask clarifying questions. Upon our inspection of the dataset, there are also various inconsistencies related to the ‚Äúsystem-side‚Äù clarification questions given in the dataset‚Äôs conversational contexts, which we highlight in Table               A7             . As a result, we propose AmbigSQL, our own synthetically constructed resource for ambiguous conversational text-to-SQL.

id_table_8.caption: The format of the black text represents how a ground-truth request would be used to form the prompt for a target example. The blue text represents the content that would be synthesized from an LLM. We omit the database schema from the paper.
table:
[ [ [ Database Schema Omitted ] ] ] The target SQL query is the following: 
SELECT professional_id ,  last_name ,  cell_number FROM Professionals
WHERE state  =  ‚ÄôIndiana‚Äô UNION SELECT T1.professional_id ,  T1.last_name ,
T1.cell_number FROM Professionals AS T1 JOIN Treatments AS T2 ON
T1.professional_id  =  T2.professional_id
GROUP BY T1.professional_id HAVING count(*)  >  2
Here is a clear request that would correspond to this SQL query: ‚ÄúWhich professionals live in the state of Indiana or have done treatment on more than 2 treatments? List his or her id, last name and cell phone.‚Äù Here is the same request converted into an ambiguous format by underspecifying the target columns: ‚ÄúWhich ones live in the state of Indiana or have done treatment on more than 2 treatments?‚Äù Here is an appropriate clarifying question to recover the clear request from the ambiguous request: ‚ÄúAre you asking about the Professionals?‚Äù
references: We focus on three fundamental types of ambiguous information requests. Those in which the requested information is ambiguous (e.g., ‚ÄúShow details about singers ordered by age from the oldest to the youngest‚Äù), those in which the requested population is ambiguous (e.g., ‚ÄúWhich ones who live in the state of Indiana?‚Äù; see Table                  A8                ), and finally, those in which the requested presentation of results is ambiguous (e.g. ‚ÄúShow name, country, age for all singers ordered by age‚Äù; see Table                  A9                ).

We iterate through each of the examples in Spider, and use an LLM (Gemini Ultra 1.0) to synthesize a perturbed version of each unambiguous query, along with an appropriate clarifying question. For queries which require some manipulation of results presentation, we prompt an LLM to perturb the query such that the requested presentation style becomes ambiguous. Otherwise, we randomly select a perturbation strategy: either masking the requested information (Table                  A9                ) or masking the requested population (Table                  A8                ). For each of these three strategies, we use five in-context examples demonstrating the appropriate masking process. The exact in-context examples are given in the attached code. Each of these ambiguous queries are thus associated with conversations containing ‚Äúground truth‚Äù states at two timesteps,                                   t                         1                                                 subscript                            ùë°                            1                                       t_{1}                       and                                   t                         2                                                 subscript                            ùë°                            2                                       t_{2}                       .                                   p                         1                                                 subscript                            ùëù                            1                                       p_{1}                       contains an ambiguous user request,                                   r                         1                                                 subscript                            ùëü                            1                                       r_{1}                       is the synthesized clarification question, and accordingly,                                             a                            1                                  =                                   C                            ‚Äã                            L                            ‚Äã                            A                            ‚Äã                            R                            ‚Äã                            I                            ‚Äã                            F                            ‚Äã                            Y                                                                                       subscript                               ùëé                               1                                                                     ùê∂                               ùêø                               ùê¥                               ùëÖ                               ùêº                               ùêπ                               ùëå                                                 a_{1}=CLARIFY                       .                                   p                         2                                                 subscript                            ùëù                            2                                       p_{2}                       contains the disambiguated user request,                                   r                         2                                                 subscript                            ùëü                            2                                       r_{2}                       is the correct ground truth SQL query, and accordingly,                                             a                            2                                  =                                   A                            ‚Äã                            N                            ‚Äã                            S                            ‚Äã                            W                            ‚Äã                            E                            ‚Äã                            R                                                                                       subscript                               ùëé                               2                                                                     ùê¥                               ùëÅ                               ùëÜ                               ùëä                               ùê∏                               ùëÖ                                                 a_{2}=ANSWER                       .

id_table_10.caption: Competitive high capacity LLMs struggle with producing ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù SQL queries given only ambiguous user requests. Including disambiguation turns in the prompts greatly improves execution match.
table: Model Ambiguous Request Execution Match Execution Match with Clarification Turns Gemini Pro 28.5 68.7 Gemini Ultra 31.2 77.0
references: is our new task for SQL-grounded conversational disambiguation.We systematically perturbed unambiguous queries from Spider, a popular text-to-SQL benchmark             [               57              ]            ,resulting in paired training examples which can be easily incorporated into contrastive RL tuning. Each trajectory is evaluated by whether the final proposed SQL query matches the ground truth query‚Äôs execution result.We provide a detailed description of AmbigSQL and its construction in Appendix                     B                   .Our motivation in constructing AmbigSQL stems from the idea that disambiguation can lead to improved task performance. We found that constructing a SQL query for an underspecified request with and without clarification turns can result in a gap in execution match of up to 45.8% (see Table                     A10                   ).

We conducted this analysis on the test set using two competitive LLMs, Gemini Pro 1.0 and Gemini Ultra 1.0, with the Execution Match tool from Spider and CoSQL           [             57            ,             65            ]          . Our results are shown in Table                  A10                . Given only an ambiguous request, both Gemini Pro and Gemini Ultra struggle to consistently construct the correct SQL query. However, given disambiguation turns, Execution Match improves dramatically, approximating the performance on the validation set given in           [             66            ,             67            ]          .

id_table_11.caption: Black text: context provided to an LLM as a prompt.text: ground-truth single-turn response.text: target trajectory which should be achieved through simulation.
table: [ [ [ Instruction ] ] ] You are an Assistant having a conversation with a User who would like to retrieve some information from a SQL database with the schema provided below. If you are confident in the User‚Äôs intent, you should provide the appropriate SQL query. Otherwise, you should ask the User a clarifying question. [ [ [ Database Schema Omitted ] ] ] [ [ [ Conversation ] ] ] User: How many singers do we have? Assistant: SELECT count(*) FROM singer [ [ [ Instruction ] ] ] You are an Assistant having a conversation with a User who would like to retrieve some information from a SQL database with the schema provided below. If you are confident in the User‚Äôs intent, you should provide the appropriate SQL query. Otherwise, you should ask the User a clarifying question. [ [ [ Database Schema Omitted ] ] ] [ [ [ Conversation ] ] ] User: Tell me about the singers. Assistant: What specifically would you like to know about the singers? For example, would you like to know how many there are, or see a list of their names? User: How many singers do we have? Assistant: SELECT count(*) FROM singer
references: Table                  A11                and Table                  A12                each contain a pair of examples from AmbigSQL‚Äôs test set. Each example contains the prompt which is provided to an LLM, the immediate ground truth response to the user request provided as part of the prompt, and the resulting ground truth trajectory (for examples which include clarifying questions). The examples in each table are paired ‚Äî the top example is directly taken from Spider and converted into a conversational format, and the bottom example is the result of introducing ambiguity into the first example.

Assistant: SELECT count(*) FROM AIRPORTS [ [ [ Instruction ] ] ] You are an Assistant having a conversation with a User who would like to retrieve some information from a SQL database with the schema provided below. If you are confident in the User‚Äôs intent, you should provide the appropriate SQL query. Otherwise, you should ask the User a clarifying question. [ [ [ Database Schema Omitted ] ] ] [ [ [ Conversation ] ] ] User: How many are there? Assistant: Could you please specify which table you are referring to when you ask ‚ÄôHow many are there?‚Äô User: Return the number of airports. Assistant: SELECT count(*) FROM AIRPORTS
references: Table                  A11                and Table                  A12                each contain a pair of examples from AmbigSQL‚Äôs test set. Each example contains the prompt which is provided to an LLM, the immediate ground truth response to the user request provided as part of the prompt, and the resulting ground truth trajectory (for examples which include clarifying questions). The examples in each table are paired ‚Äî the top example is directly taken from Spider and converted into a conversational format, and the bottom example is the result of introducing ambiguity into the first example.

id_table_13.caption: Thetext is the overall system instruction. Thetext is what an LLM would have to produce at inference time.
table: You are an Assistant answering questions from a User. You should either attempt to answer the question or ask a clarifying question if there is any ambiguity. [ [ [ Table and Passage Omitted ] ] ] User: How much does the company expect to make contributions to the defined plans during the next fiscal year? Assistant: [‚ÄôWhat kind of defined plans are you asking about?‚Äô] User: The defined benefit plans and the defined contribution plan respectively. Assistant: [‚Äô$5.1 million‚Äô, ‚Äô$0.6 million‚Äô] User: What is the value of the expected defined contribution plan as a percentage of the defined benefit plan during the next fiscal year? Assistant: 0.6/5.1 = 11.76 User: How much would change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively in the discount rate? Assistant: [‚ÄôWhat kind of change are you asking about?‚Äô] User: The pension. Assistant: [‚Äô$(39,145)‚Äô, ‚Äô$49,361‚Äô] User: What is the difference in that amount if the discount rate had a 1% increase and a 1% decrease? Assistant: 49,361 - (39,145) = 88506 User: How much would the pension change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively? Assistant: [‚ÄôWhich rate of increase and decrease are you talking about?‚Äô] User: The future salary growth. Assistant: [‚Äô$7,572‚Äô, ‚Äô$(6,919)‚Äô] User: What is the difference between them? Assistant: 7,572 - (6,919) = 14491
references: We simply provide in-context examples that are structurally identical to the inputs used for model tuning. Our format is similar to the formats used in           [             24            ,             59            ]          and we provide an example in Table                  A13                .

id_table_14.caption: Thetext is the overall system instruction. Thetext is what an LLM would have to produce at inference time.
table: You are an Assistant answering questions from a User. You should either attempt to answer the question or ask a clarifying question if there is any ambiguity. [ [ [ Table and Passage Omitted ] ] ] User: What is the value of the expected defined contribution plan as a percentage of the defined benefit plan during the next fiscal year? Instruction: If the user‚Äôs question is ambiguous, ask an appropriate clarifying question. Otherwise, directly answer the user‚Äôs question using the information from the passage context and the table. Let‚Äôs think step by step. Reasoning: The user‚Äôs question is not ambiguous. Assistant: 0.6/5.1 = 11.76 User: How much would change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively in the discount rate? Instruction: If the user‚Äôs question is ambiguous, ask an appropriate clarifying question. Otherwise, directly answer the user‚Äôs question using the information from the passage context and the table. Let‚Äôs think step by step. Reasoning: The user‚Äôs question was ambiguous. Assistant: [‚ÄôWhat kind of change are you asking about?‚Äô] User: The pension. Instruction: If the user‚Äôs question is ambiguous, ask an appropriate clarifying question. Otherwise, directly answer the user‚Äôs question using the information from the passage context and the table. Let‚Äôs think step by step. Reasoning: The user‚Äôs question is not ambiguous. Assistant: [‚Äô$(39,145)‚Äô, ‚Äô$49,361‚Äô] User: What is the difference in that amount if the discount rate had a 1% increase and a 1% decrease? Instruction: If the user‚Äôs question is ambiguous, ask an appropriate clarifying question. Otherwise, directly answer the user‚Äôs question using the information from the passage context and the table. Let‚Äôs think step by step. Reasoning: The user‚Äôs question is not ambiguous. Assistant: 49,361 - (39,145) = 88506 User: How much would the pension change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively? Instruction: If the user‚Äôs question is ambiguous, ask an appropriate clarifying question. Otherwise, directly answer the user‚Äôs question using the information from the passage context and the table. Let‚Äôs think step by step. Reasoning: The user‚Äôs question was ambiguous. Assistant: [‚ÄôWhich rate of increase and decrease are you talking about?‚Äô]
references: We integrate the popular reasoning framework, chain-of-thought prompting           [             58            ]          into our aforementioned ‚ÄúStandard‚Äù conversational prompt format. Effectively, we ask an LLM to do end-to-end dialogue generation by having it first produce a reasoning chain which states whether the current context is ambiguous or not. We provide an example in Table                  A14                .

id_table_15.caption: Thetext is the overall system instruction. Thetext is what an LLM would have to produce at inference time.
table: You are an Assistant answering questions from a User. You should either attempt to answer the question or ask a clarifying question if there is any ambiguity. [ [ [ Table and Passage Omitted ] ] ] User: How much does the company expect to make contributions to the defined plans during the next fiscal year? The user‚Äôs last question was ambiguous. The Assistant asks a clarifying question. Assistant: [‚ÄôWhat kind of defined plans are you asking about?‚Äô] User: The defined benefit plans and the defined contribution plan respectively. The user‚Äôs last question was unambiguous. The Assistant directly answers the question. Assistant: [‚Äô 5.1 m i l l i o n ‚Ä≤ , ‚Ä≤ 5.1million^{\prime},^{\prime} 0.6 million‚Äô] User: What is the value of the expected defined contribution plan as a percentage of the defined benefit plan during the next fiscal year? The user‚Äôs last question was unambiguous. The Assistant directly answers the question. Assistant: 0.6/5.1 = 11.76 User: How much would change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively in the discount rate? The user‚Äôs last question was ambiguous. The Assistant asks a clarifying question. Assistant: [‚ÄôWhat kind of change are you asking about?‚Äô] User: The pension. The user‚Äôs last question was unambiguous. The Assistant directly answers the question. Assistant: [‚Äô ( 39 , 145 ) ‚Ä≤ , ‚Ä≤ (39,145)^{\prime},^{\prime} 49,361‚Äô] User: What is the difference in that amount if the discount rate had a 1% increase and a 1% decrease? The user‚Äôs last question was unambiguous. The Assistant directly answers the question. Assistant: 49,361 - (39,145) = 88506 User: How much would the pension change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively? Actions: [‚ÄúDirectly Answer‚Äù, ‚ÄúAsk a Clarification Question‚Äù] Prompt: Given the task background and the conversation history, please use appropriate actions to generate the response. Response: The user‚Äôs last question was ambiguous. The Assistant asks a clarifying question. Assistant: [‚ÄôWhich rate of increase and decrease are you talking about?‚Äô]
references: Following the baselines given in           [             34            ]          , we apply the Proactive Prompting framework           [             59            ]          mixed with the Mixed-Initiative Prompting style           [             24            ]          . Ultimately, the LLM conditions on the possible set of actions, along with interweaved natural language instructions that describe which actions correspond to existing dialogue turns. We provide an example in Table                  A15                . We use this framework for each of the long-context dialogue corpora (PACIFIC and Abg-CoQA).

id_table_16.caption: Thetext represents the action for this example.
table: [ [ [ Table and Passage Omitted ] ] ] User: What was the total number of acquisitions in FY19? Assistant: 35 acquisitions User: What are the benefits of active growth strategy? Assistant: strengthens and scales the National Storage operating platform which drives efficiencies across the business. User: What was the total NLA? Assistant: Which region are you asking about? The last Assistant utterance is a clarifying question.
references: Table               A16             is an example of an in-context example used to demonstrate a system-side response with the ‚ÄúClarify‚Äù action in PACIFIC (‚ÄúAssistant: Which region are you asking about?‚Äù). All of the conversation history is made available in addition to the relevant table and passage in the prompt. We include all contextual information available as part of the input to the Action Classifier, along with the last Assistant response which is an example of the classification target.

id_table_17.caption: Thetext represents the action for this example.
table: [ [ [ Passage Omitted ] ] ] User: And who in the group was anxious? Assistant: Peppe User: Was she well-rested? Assistant: no The last Assistant utterance is a direct answer.
references: Table               A17             is an example of an in-context example used to demonstrate a system-side response with the ‚ÄúAnswer‚Äù action in Abg-CoQA (‚ÄúAssistant: no‚Äù). As is common in this corpus, a subset of the conversation is made available in addition to the relevant passage in the prompt. We include all contextual information available as part of the input to the Action Classifier, along with the last Assistant response which is an example of the classification target.

id_table_18.caption: Thetext represents the action for this example.
table:
[ [ [ Database Schema Omitted ] ] ] User: ‚ÄúWhich professionals live in the state of Indiana or have done treatment on more than 2 treatments? List his or her id, last name and cell phone.‚Äù Here is the same request converted into an ambiguous format by underspecifying the target columns: Assistant: 
SELECT professional_id ,  last_name ,  cell_number FROM Professionals
WHERE state  =  ‚ÄôIndiana‚Äô UNION SELECT T1.professional_id ,  T1.last_name ,
T1.cell_number FROM Professionals AS T1 JOIN Treatments AS T2 ON
T1.professional_id  =  T2.professional_id
GROUP BY T1.professional_id HAVING count(*)  >  2
The last Assistant utterance is a direct answer.
references: Table               A18             is an example of an in-context example used to demonstrate a system-side response with the ‚ÄúAnswer‚Äù action in AmbigSQL. In AmbigSQL, the information provided as input is the database schema, and the user‚Äôs initial information request. This information is provided as part of the input to the Action Classifier, along with the last Assistant response which is an example of the classification target.

id_table_19.caption: Thetext represents the system prompt used for this task. Thetext represents the summarized information-seeking intents.
table: The following is a conversation between a User and an Assistant. The User is asking some questions. Summarize what information the User is looking for. [ [ [ Table and Passage Omitted ] ] ] User: What does Walletron deliver? Assistant: patented mobile wallet technology. User: How much did it cost the company to acquire certain technology assets of RevChip, LLC ("RevChip") and TranSend Integrated Technologies Inc. ("TranSend")? Assistant: $7.0 million User: What was the pro forma revenue in 2019? Assistant: $1,382,957 User: What was the change in its amount between 2018 and 2019? Assistant: 21228 User: How about that in pro forma net income? Assistant: -6425 [Information] The user wants to know: 1. What technology Walletron delivers, 2. How much it cost Walletron to acquire certain technology assets of RevChip, LLC and TranSend Integrated Technologies Inc., 3. What the pro forma revenue was in 2019, 4. What the change in pro forma revenue was between 2018 and 2019, and 5. What the change in pro forma net income was between 2018 and 2019.
references: We provide one of our three handcrafted in-context examples of summarizing information-seeking intent in Table                  A19                . While the information summary is handcrafted, the conversation and grounding data are taken directly from the PACIFIC. After intent summarization,                          U                               ùëà                              U                       is given the existing conversation history along with an instruction that includes the information seeking intents and asked to provide the next user response. This format is structurally the same as the three simulation-specific in-context examples ‚Äî an example is provided in Table                  A20                .

How much it cost Walletron to acquire certain technology assets of RevChip, LLC and TranSend Integrated Technologies Inc., 3. What the pro forma revenue was in 2019, 4. What the change in pro forma revenue was between 2018 and 2019, and 5. What the change in pro forma net income was between 2018 and 2019. Assistant: 21228 User: How about that in pro forma net income? Assistant: -6425
references: We provide one of our three handcrafted in-context examples of summarizing information-seeking intent in Table                  A19                . While the information summary is handcrafted, the conversation and grounding data are taken directly from the PACIFIC. After intent summarization,                          U                               ùëà                              U                       is given the existing conversation history along with an instruction that includes the information seeking intents and asked to provide the next user response. id_table_21.caption: The purple text represents the system prompt used for this task. The blue text represents the summarized information-seeking intents.
table: [ [ [ Passage Omitted ] ] ] User: What was his ranking? Assistant: General User: Did someone else have horse fighters? Assistant: yes User: Who? Assistant: Do you want to know who had 2,500 horse fighters initially? User: No, I want to know who had a considerable force of horse fighters west of him. Assistant: General (Bishop) Polk. Instruction: Summarize what information the user is looking for. Summary: The user wants to know: 1. What his ranking was. 2. Whether someone else had horse fighters. 3. Who had a considerable force of horse fighters west of him.
references: We conduct user simulation for Abg-CoQA similarly to PACIFIC. Table                  A21                is one of three hand-crafted examples of intent summarization, and Table                  A22                is one of three hand-crafted examples used for simulating the final user response.

id_table_22.caption: Thetext represents the system prompt used for this task, which contains the information-seeking intents summarized from Table. The entire conversation is used for this example to demonstrate grounding between a conversation and intents.
table: The following is a snippet from a conversation between an Assistant and a User who is asking some questions about the Story below. The user only wants to know the following information: 1. What his ranking was. 2. Whether someone else had horse fighters. 3. Who had a considerable force of horse fighters west of him. [ [ [ Passage Omitted ] ] ] User: What was his ranking? Assistant: General User: Did someone else have horse fighters? Assistant: yes User: Who? Assistant: Do you want to know who had 2,500 horse fighters initially? User: No, I want to know who had a considerable force of horse fighters west of him. Assistant: General (Bishop) Polk.
references: We conduct user simulation for Abg-CoQA similarly to PACIFIC. id_table_23.caption: Thetext represents the system prompt used for this task, which contains ground truth SQL query goal. The entire conversation is used for this example to demonstrate SQL query-grounded request disambiguation.
table:
A user is asking an assistant to retrieve some information from a SQL database. The command that the assistant should ultimately return is as follows: 
SELECT county FROM campuses where campus = ‚ÄôCalifornia State University-Chico‚Äô
The assistant will ask some questions to clarify the user‚Äôs intent. The user should respond with a rephrased request that reflects their desired query. User: what is the county? Assistant: Are you asking for a list of all of the counties in the database? User: I‚Äôm looking for the county of the campus ‚ÄôCalifornia State University-Chico‚Äô
references: We conduct user simulation slightly differently for AmbigSQL. Rather than having a separate step for knowledge-seeking intent summarization, we directly condition                          U                               ùëà                              U                       on the target SQL query. As demonstrated in Table                  A23                , the prompt includes the target SQL query, the original user request, and the clarification question sampled from the Assistant. In the example given in Table                  A23                , the last line is the ground truth disambiguated query, and in practice, this would be the generation target of                          U                               ùëà                              U                       .

id_table_24.caption: . Left: snippet of from a passage from the PACIFIC test set. Middle: trajectory resulting from the SFT model in response to the user query. Right: trajectory resulting from themodel. Red text: sampled from. Both the SFT andmodel answered the question incorrectly.
table: Relevant Data Net profit/(loss) after tax was $(9.8) million Net profit/(loss) after tax : (9,819) || 6,639 || (248%) Relevant Data Net profit/(loss) after tax was $(9.8) million Net profit/(loss) after tax : (9,819) || 6,639 || (248%) SFT ACT Relevant Data Net profit/(loss) after tax was $(9.8) million Net profit/(loss) after tax : (9,819) || 6,639 || (248%) User: What was the net profit/(loss) after tax? User: What was the net profit/(loss) after tax? Assistant: $(9,819) √ó \times Assistant: Which year are you asking the amount of? User: FY19 Assistant: $(9,819) √ó \times
references: Table               A24             includes an erroneous trajectory produced by the         ACT        model in the 50 conversation setting of PACIFIC. In this particular example, both the provided passage and the provided table provided similar information regarding net profit/loss after tax. In the dataset, the ground truth answer selected a span from the passage, whereas the         ACT        model produced a clarification question and then eventually an answer using tabular information. The SFT model directly assumed the intent of the user and similarly produced an answer from the tabular information.

id_table_25.caption: . Left: snippet of from a passage from the PACIFIC test set. Middle: trajectory resulting from the SFT model in response to the user query. Right: trajectory resulting from themodel. Red text: sampled from. Both the SFT andmodel answered the question incorrectly, and neither asked a clarification question.
table: Relevant Table Data Year: 2019 || 2018 Investments: 1,216.0 || 1,212.9 Relevant Table Data Year: 2019 || 2018 Investments: 1,216.0 || 1,212.9 SFT ACT Relevant Table Data Year: 2019 || 2018 Investments: 1,216.0 || 1,212.9 User: In which year was the amount of Investments higher? User: In which year was the amount of Investments higher? Assistant: [2018] √ó \times Assistant: [2018, 2019] √ó \times
references: Table               A25             includes another pair of erroneous trajectories in the 50 conversation setting of PACIFIC. The requested information was accessible through the provided table data, but both the SFT model and the         ACT        model failed to produce the correct answer. This example was not annotated as requiring a clarifying question, so it simply indicates that there is much room for improvement in terms of downstream task performance.

id_table_26.caption: . Left: snippet of a relevant passage from the Abg-CoQA test set. Middle: trajectory resulting from the SFT model in response to the user query. Right: trajectory resulting from themodel. Red text: sampled from. Ground truth outcome: Meghan asked Lizzie,‚ÄúAre you awake?‚Äù
table: Relevant Passage She yawned, stretching out like a lazy cat. Her sister was also awake. "Lizzie", Meghan whispered, "are you awake?" Relevant Passage She yawned, stretching out like a lazy cat. Her sister was also awake. "Lizzie", Meghan whispered, "are you awake?" SFT ACT Relevant Passage She yawned, stretching out like a lazy cat. Her sister was also awake. "Lizzie", Meghan whispered, "are you awake?" User: What did Meghan ask? User: What did Meghan ask? Assistant: Do you mean where did Lizzie see her father? Assistant: Do you mean that morning or the night before? User: No User: The night before. Assistant: Lizzie had only met her father in person once, according to the story. √ó \times Assistant: Meghan asked Lizzie if she was awake that morning. ‚úì
references: Table               A26             includes a pair of trajectories resulting from SFT and         ACT        in the 50 conversation setting of Abg-CoQA. The requested information is given in the portion of the passage in the left panel. The SFT model asked an off-topic clarification question and failed to bring the qestioning on track. The         ACT        model successfully asked an on-track clarification question and eventually produced the correct answer.
